awd_titl_txt: Materials World Network:  Critical Scaling of Domain Dynamics in Ferroelectric Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Research into electronic behavior of ferroelectrics is an important and challenging scientific problem related to fundamental physical properties of complex oxide materials. One of the particularly promising aspects of this research is the dynamic behavior of low-dimensional ferroelectric structures with constrained geometry in the external electric field. For the vast majority of applications, it is the switching and the associated evolution of domain structure that is the cornerstone for device functionality. This research will answer questions related to interplay between complex geometry, size and dynamics of polarization reversal in nanoscale ferroelectric structures and the fundamental scaling limits to ferroelectric-based devices, such as high-density non-volatile memory and data storage devices, spin filters and microwave devices. International student exchange is an essential component of the project contributing to the well-coordinated collaborative research between US and European partners. The UK portion of the work is supported by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC). Students recruited into this project from underrepresented groups, in particular, are benefiting from exposure to international research through the enrichment of their professional preparation and education experience. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project is investigating and seeking to understand the manner in which reduced size and increased morphological complexity affect the switching behavior of meso- and nanoscale ferroelectrics. The experimental approach involves fabrication of free-standing single-crystalline nanoplates, nanorods and nanodots of a model ferroelectric BaTiO3 and characterization of its dynamic switching behavior by means of an advanced 'stroboscopic' Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (S-PFM) method. The samples are being prepared using a Focused Ion Beam (FIB) technique and then structurally characterized at Queen's University Belfast (QUB), UK, in the group of Prof. John Martin Gregg.  Prior research has demonstrated that the FIB mode of fabrication gives particularly clear insight into the fundamental behaviour of ferroelectrics at reduced scales. S-PFM is being used to map the dynamics of domain wall motion during in-plane switching, induced by an external electric field applied between coplanar electrodes. FIB-engineered defects in the thin ferroelectric slabs, such as holes, notches and slits, allow direct studies of the manner in which physical defects alter the nucleation and propagation of domain walls. The outcome of the project will lead to fundamental advances in understanding the role of electrical and mechanical boundary conditions and sample scaling on the basic mechanisms of ferroelectric switching.

NSF Materials World Network program (DMR-1007943): “Critical Scaling of Domain Dynamics in Ferroelectric Nanostructures” 

            This research was focused on investigation of the domain switching behavior in ferroelectric single crystals with a size of just several micrometers. The research brought together complementary expertise from experimental labs in the USA and UK: Prof Gruverman at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) has pioneered time-resolved Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (PFM) as a technique for monitoring switching dynamics in small scale ferroelectrics while Prof Gregg at the Queen’s University Belfast (QUB) has been pioneering novel experiments on size effects in nanoscale ferroelectrics. This project involved fabrication of free-standing single-crystalline lamellae of a model ferroelectric BaTiO3 by Focused Ion Beam (FIB) etching and characterization of their static and dynamic domain configurations by means of time-resolved PFM imaging.

            Intellectual merit. One of the major finding of the project is observation of a new type of domain patterns composed of four quadrants of 90° stripe domains – the so-called flux closure domain quadrants - in single crystal BaTiO3 (Fig 1). It is shown that relatively large-scale ferroelectric closure states do not form spontaneously on cooling through the Curie temperature. Rather formation of these patterns is related to a dynamical process resulting from system relaxation after the BaTiO3 has been poled with a uniform electric field.

Another major finding of this project is related to clarification of the complex structure of the super domain boundary (SDB) in a free-standing single-crystalline BaTiO3 lamellae. The SDB consists of segmented 180° domain wall sections separating a-c stripe domain bundles, which change their orientation at the SDB (Fig 2). Application of the in-plane electric field using FIB-fabricated electrodes and time-resolved PFM visualization of domain structure allowed investigation of the SDB dynamics. Detailed inspection at the nanoscale level using in-situ PFM imaging (i.e. in the presence of a planar external switching field) showed that the switching process occurred via reversal of in-plane a-subdomains. The obtained results show that the SDB after initial quick acceleration slows down shortly after application of uniform electric field (Fig 2). We suggest that this behavior is determined by the interplay between the emergence and screening of a depolarising field of newly switched c-subdomains that acts to negate the driving force of the planar external field. Under uniform field application, domain wall position depends logarithmically on time and its average velocity profile scales inversely with time.

            Broader impact. The obtained results represent a major step forward in the search for novel ferroelectric topologies and in fundamental understanding of structural transformations and scaling behavior in ferroelectric/multiferroic materials.

Graduate students from UNL and QUB paid visits to the partner laboratories to participate in FIB sample fabrication and PFM characterization activities.
